oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Eddie Rabbitt Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Eddie Rabbitt (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Eddie Rabbitt; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Eddie Rabbitt declares that the production on his album Jersey Boy is a pride of his, and Rabbitt thanks Richard Landis for his production -- (00:25) Rabbitt radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (00:34) Rabbitt says ""Move over Biff, I'm your cohost this week"" -- (00:39) Rabbitt messes up radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (00:46) Collie laughs during Rabbitt radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (00:53) Rabbitt radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (01:00) Rabbitt radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (01:07) Collie and Rabbitt discuss the upcoming review for Jersey Boy, released by Capitol Records -- (01:17) Rabbitt and Collie joke about Rabbitt's pair of t-shirts, and Rabbitt reveals how he had wanted a Jersey Boy t-shirt for a promotion with Dean Markley Strings -- (2:00) Rabbitt reveals how he wrote, Ronnie Milsap's first number one record, ""Pure Love"" -- (02:13) Rabbitt reveals his pride in writing, Elvis Presley's fiftieth gold record, ""Kentucky Rain"" -- (02:21) Rabbitt tells that the first song he had recorded in Nashville was Roy Drusky's ""Working My Way Up to the Bottom"" -- (02:36) Collie and Rabbitt discuss how ""Jersey Boy"" became the title track and Rabbitt reflects on how a number of his songs he writes he does not release -- (03:37) Rabbitt tells of how he got his first exposure to country music from his scout leader; as well as, from his father's fiddle playing -- (04:31) Rabbitt and Collie discuss Rabbitt's Irish heritage and his families extensive musical background -- (05:36) Collie introduces the format of the album review and Rabbitt reflects on his country music roots and country music's connection to Ireland -- (06:49) Rabbitt calls ""Tennessee Born and Bred"" the epidemy of bluegrass 'All American' music -- (07:18) Collie says he will play ""Tennessee Born and Bred"" for Rabbitt -- (07:27) Rabbitt discusses how he stayed at Reed Nielsen's apartment while recording ""Tennessee Born and Bred"" with a number of bluegrass legends -- (08:22) Rabbitt says 'Welcome to the music business' -- (08:28) Rabbitt discusses his unease when it comes to complacency, Collie likes the terminology Rabbitt uses, and Rabbitt asserts his normality -- (09:40) Rabbitt discusses his desire to write a song similar Ray Price and being asked to write a song while on the tour bus -- (10:39) Rabbitt tells of how he recorded his music video to be a replica of a 1950s barn yard party -- (11:21) Collie brings up ""The Wanderer's"" music video and Rabbitt gives praise to Jack Cole -- (11:38) Rabbitt tells how ""Suspicions"" had been written in five minutes -- (12:05) Rabbitt describes ""They're Tearin' My Little Town Down"" to be a song about small towns turning into 'ghost towns' -- (12:51) Collie has Rabbitt recall how Rabbitt wrote ""American Boy"" while riding on a moped in Bermuda -- (14:26) Rabbitt talks about the obsessive repetition he had when he was trying to memorize ""American Boy"" -- (15:27) Collie recaps the show to that point and Rabbitt jokingly thanks Collie for coming on his show -- (15:54) Collie recalls and has Rabbitt tell about the time he made an ashtray, for his father, in the side of his father's chair -- (17:35) ""Hold on to Me (The Rain Song)"" is discussed by Rabbitt to be a song build off a melody that Nielsen was playing one day at the studio, and Rabbitt reveals his three-year-old son's immediate love for the song -- (19:14) Rabbitt continues to tell of his son's enjoyment of ""Hold on to Me (The Rain Song)"" including his son's love of the thunder sound effects -- (19:27) ""Feel Like a Stranger"" is discussed to be a 'Louisiana mud swamp' type song about someone who feels like a stranger in their own home -- (20:25) Collie has Rabbitt recall attempting to sell country songs in New York and Rabbitt tells about how he brought a fifty pound recorder with him everywhere -- (22:28) Rabbitt recalls having an interview with Shapiro, Bernstein & Co. and how he was offered $25 a week -- (24:34) Rabbitt says ""It's Lonely Out Tonite"" is a country-rock song and Rabbitt says it invites people to come across the room to meet each other -- (25:12) Collie has Rabbitt discuss his plan of attack when it comes to recording an album and Rabbitt discusses how he can start with over thirty songs -- (27:05) ""Suspicions"" is revealed to be an add-on to an already complete album -- (28:25) Rabbitt reveals how he didn't believe that ""Sweet Janine"" was going to be a recorded track -- (29:20) ""Jersey Boy"" is revealed to be an autobiography for Rabbitt -- (30:23) Rabbitt says ""I just like it, it's a real nice song about what happened to me"" -- (30:29) Rabbitt recalls a time he was touring through Montana and he and Nielsen were in the right mood to write ""Only One Love in My Life"" -- (31:07) Collie praises Rabbitt's efforts and Collie has Rabbitt discuss his children's names, and Rabbitt tells how his daughter Demelza got her name officially authenticated from English writer Winston Graham -- (33:22) Collie speaks praise and Rabbitt speaks of his idea on having children with a single woman -- (33:58) Collie recaps the subject of the show and Rabbitt expresses his interest in being on the show again
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Rabbitt, Eddie; Rabbitt, Eddie, 1941-1998; Collie, Biff;
